## Classic examples of perverse incentives:
<hr>
<br/>

**French colonial government in Honoi paying locals to exterminate rats &#8594;<span style="color:darkred">led to the farming of rats and increased rat problem</span>**

<br/>
<br/>
<br/>
<br/>
<br/>
<br/>
<br/>
<br/>

**Carbon credits grant nations the right to emit gases that contribute to global warming. Developed nations are able to earn carbon credits by investing in emissions-reduction projects &#8594;<span style="color:darkred"> For greenhouse gases trifluoromethane and sulfur hexafluoride, the value of the credits obtained can exceed the cost of destroying these gases in the production process, creating a 'perverse' incentive to increase production so that credits can be claimed.</span>**


<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:235px; LEFT:275px; WIDTH:500px; HEIGHT:200px" SRC="images/mouse2.png">

## Endangered Species Act
<hr>
<br/>

**One of the most important pieces of legislation on biodiversity in the US**

<br/>

**There are > 2,200 species listed as endangered or threatened in the US **

<br/>

**In total there have been 94 species de-listed**
<br/>
**<span style="color:blue">62 due to recovery</span>**
<br/>
**<span style="color:blue">11 due to extinction</span>**
<br/>
**<span style="color:blue">21 due to “original data in error”</span>**

## Endangered Species Act is powerful but complicated
<hr>
<br/>

**<span style="color:blue">What incentive structure does the ESA establish?</span>**
<br/>

**<span style="color:darkred">What are some perverse incentives that the ESA might unintentionally establish?</span>**

## Endangered Species Act is powerful but complicated
<hr>
<br/>

**<span style="color:blue">What incentive structure does the ESA establish?</span>**
<br/>

**<span style="color:darkred">What are some perverse incentives that the ESA might unintentionally establish?</span>**
<br/>

* **Pre-emptive habitat destruction (to prevent endangered species from establishing, e.g., harvesting trees early so they don’t become old enough to become suitable habitat)**

<br/>

* **Direct removal of endangered species (to prevent government from imposing restrictions on the land, e.g., “shoot, shovel and shut up”)**

<br/>

* **Increased harvest of endangered species to make money off their rarity**

<br/>

* **Focus on individual species instead of ecosystem**

<hr>
<br/>

<br/>
<br/>

**Often discussed in financial terms, but also deep humanitarian and environmental justice concerns **
